author: 0xalizk
content:
These two are mutually exclusive, both can't be true: 
(a) floating escalator makes sense and users will use it if implemented or they'll simulate its effect (i.e. riding the wave of `basefee` ) if it's not thru re-submission by themselves or thru 3rd party services and 
(b) EIP1559 removes the need to worry about tip most of the time.

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: The key word is "**most** of the time".

author: sky.cactus
content: Escalator tips (or re-submission with increased tip) is useful in the 5% case (percentage is an example number).

author: sky.cactus
content: For the remaining 95% case (still an example number), users can ignore tips.

author: 0xalizk
content: There is so much tight coupling between everything it makes me nervous to be honest. I like Barnabe's floating version, but still on the fence about having escalation in-protocol .. it's very feasible to simulate it in wallet (at some expense of some added network traffic due to re-submission with same nonce)

author: sky.cactus
content: It is less efficient at layer 2, and the UX is *much* worse, especially for things like hardware wallets where you cannot trivially sign a dozen transactions at once.

author: 0xalizk
content: Doesn't walletconnect work with hardware wallets? I mean users are not limited to the UI of their HD wallets. There is also the option of smart on-chain wallets + relayer pattern which I think solves this HD issue as well

author: sky.cactus
content: All hardware wallets on the market require a separate signature for every transaction.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you want to sign a dozen transactions with different gas prices, you have to sign a dozen separate transactions on your hardware wallet.

author: 0xalizk
content: Ah I see. But there could be a UI/UX around that no? It's not a fundamental limitation to the point where the base protocol should internalize these concerns

author: sky.cactus
content: In theory hardware wallets could be update such that they can sign a dozen transactions with different gas prices with a single user interaction.

author: sky.cactus
content: That would be a pretty large change and be *very* Ethereum specific.  At the moment, hardware wallets are basically just ECDSA signers, they may have a bit of UI specific to different chains, but at their core they just "ECDA sign when user clicks OK".

author: sky.cactus
content: Even if they did support signing multiple transactions with one interaction, you still have other UX problems like actually serving up the different transactions at different times (requires an app that remains online/running for the duration of escalation).

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, manual escalations have to be 12% increases per step, while escalator is just a linear function of time.

author: sky.cactus
content: Escalator also has a nice side effect of encouraging miners to improve timestamp accuracy.  Right now, many miners set the timestamp to old (e.g., 30 seconds old) because it gives them a *very marginal advantage*.  This isn't a big problem, but it would be nice if there was a mild incentive to use a more accurate timestamp in each block.

author: sky.cactus
content: So while I agree that escalator *can* be implemented (more or less) at a higher layer, I think there are *enough* benefits of it being on layer 1 to be worthwhile.

author: 0xalizk
content: I guess it depends on one's tolerance for "internalizing concerns" into the base protocol. Personally I see it as a last-resort kind of thing, a "thin protocol maximalist" if you will.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think that is a valid and reasonable position to hold.

author: sky.cactus
content: And for escalator, probably the strongest argument against it IMO.

author: timbeiko
content:
> I am not a fan of the escalator outside the protocol personally. For the HD wallets implications and mainly regarding scalability. The network overhead impact would be too high IMO.
Another thing related to this: eth/65 was just introduced as a networking protocol to reduce the bandwidth used by gossiping full transactions on the network. IIRC, it was ~75% of the bandwidth usage for Geth nodes (I assume post sync?). If "escalator outside the protocol" becomes the norm, I think it's safe to assume this will consume a majority of the gossiping bandwidth on the network. That makes me slightly against it, but I think I would need to understand better how often it would happen (i.e. if it's only needed in the "5% of time" as per Derbit's analysis, how much bandwidth is that? OTOH, if it's only needed 5% of the time, how likely is it to actually get implemented by most wallets?)

author: sendmoodz
content: there are technical challenges with rebroadcast outside the protocol, argent already does it and one ux issue with it is every rebroadcast gets a new tx hash so dapps have no way of knowing whether the original transaction hash was ever mined (unless we introduce some kind of 'hashChanged' event for rebroadcast). plus unless you rebroadcast every block and somehow get that transaction to every mining node you aren't going to match the auction efficiency of in-protocol.
